2.text: O that my provocation were thoroughly weighed, And my calamity in balances They would lift up together!

3.text: For now, than the sands of the sea it is heavier, Therefore my words have been rash.

4.text: For arrows of the Mighty are with me, Whose poison is drinking up my spirit. Terrors of God array themselves for me!

5.text: Brayeth a wild ass over tender grass? Loweth an ox over his provender?

6.text: Eaten is an insipid thing without salt? Is there sense in the drivel of dreams?

7.text: My soul is refusing to touch! They are as my sickening food.

8.text: O that my request may come, That God may grant my hope!

9.text: That God would please—and bruise me, Loose His hand and cut me off!

10.text: And yet it is my comfort, (And I exult in pain—He doth not spare,) That I have not hidden The sayings of the Holy One.

11.text: What is my power that I should hope? And what mine end That I should prolong my life?

12.text: Is my strength the strength of stones? Is my flesh brazen?

13.text: Is not my help with me, And substance driven from me?

14.text: To a despiser of his friends is shame, And the fear of the Mighty he forsaketh.

15.text: My brethren have deceived as a brook, As a stream of brooks they pass away.

16.text: That are black because of ice, By them doth snow hide itself.

17.text: By the time they are warm they have been cut off, By its being hot they have been Extinguished from their place.

18.text: Turn aside do the paths of their way, They ascend into emptiness, and are lost.

19.text: Passengers of Tema looked expectingly, Travellers of Sheba hoped for them.

20.text: They were ashamed that one hath trusted, They have come unto it and are confounded.

21.text: Surely now ye have become the same! Ye see a downfall, and are afraid.

22.text: Is it because I said, Give to me? And, By your power bribe for me?

23.text: And, Deliver me from the hand of an adversary? And, From the hand of terrible ones ransom me?

24.text: Shew me, and I—I keep silent, And what I have erred, let me understand.

25.text: How powerful have been upright sayings, And what doth reproof from you reprove?

26.text: For reproof—do you reckon words? And for wind—sayings of the desperate.

27.text: Anger on the fatherless ye cause to fall, And are strange to your friend.

28.text: And, now, please, look upon me, Even to your face do I lie?

29.text: Turn back, I pray you, let it not be perverseness, Yea, turn back again—my righteousness is in it.

30.text: Is there in my tongue perverseness? Discerneth not my palate desirable things?
